Measurable Impact of AMR Guardian:

Lives Saved: Reduce AMR-related deaths by 15-20% in participating regions through early detection of resistant strains and faster treatment adjustments, potentially preventing thousands of deaths annually.

Cost Savings: Generate $50-100M in annual healthcare cost savings through reduced hospital stays, optimized antibiotic procurement, and prevention of resistance spread across participating healthcare systems.

Surveillance Speed: Accelerate outbreak detection from weeks to days, with 90% of facilities reporting resistance cases within 24 hours, enabling rapid containment responses.

Clinical Outcomes: Achieve 30% reduction in inappropriate broad-spectrum antibiotic use through AI-powered stewardship recommendations and real-time resistance pattern monitoring.

Global Reach: Support 50+ countries in coordinating AMR response efforts, with 100,000+ healthcare workers accessing evidence-based treatment guidelines annually.

Data-Driven Policy: Enable governments to make informed resource allocation decisions backed by real-time surveillance data, tracking 1M+ resistance cases globally to identify trends and intervention opportunities.
x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is projected to cause 39.1 million deaths cumulatively from 2025 to 2050, representing one of the most critical global health threats. The supporting links are: https://www.unep.org/topics/chemicals-and-pollution-action/chemicals-management/pollution-and-health/antimicrobial and https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/antimicrobial-resistance. Healthcare facilities, governments, and NGOs struggle with: Fragmented AMR Data Collection: Hospitals, laboratories, and clinics operate in silos, making it difficult to track resistance patterns across regions Delayed Response to Outbreaks: Manual reporting processes delay identification of emerging resistant strains Inadequate Antibiotic Stewardship: Lack of real-time monitoring leads to inappropriate antibiotic prescribing Poor Surveillance Coordination: Multiple stakeholders (WHO, CDC, local health authorities) struggle to coordinate monitoring efforts Limited Resource Allocation: Inability to predict and allocate resources (specialized drugs, expertise) where needed most Knowledge Gap: Healthcare workers in resource-limited settings lack access to current AMR trends and treatment guidelines

x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.solution_proposal:
How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

ServiceNow Customer Service Management (CSM)

Use Case: Central intake portal for AMR case reporting

Capabilities:

Multi-channel case creation (web portal, mobile app, API integration) Knowledge base for treatment guidelines and AMR protocols

Automated case routing based on pathogen type and severity  SLA tracking for response times

Self-service portal for healthcare workers to report resistance cases

ServiceNow Health & Life Sciences Service Management

Use Case: Healthcare-specific workflows and compliance

Capabilities:

HIPAA-compliant data handling Patient privacy protection

Clinical trial tracking for new antimicrobials Regulatory compliance management

Healthcare provider credentialing

ServiceNow Performance Analytics

Use Case: Real-time AMR trend analysis and predictive modeling

Capabilities:

Interactive dashboards showing resistance trends by region, pathogen, and antibiotic Predictive analytics for outbreak forecasting

     Benchmarking across healthcare facilities

    Custom KPIs: resistance rates, antibiotic usage, treatment outcomes

    Time-series analysis for pattern detection

ServiceNow Integration Hub

Use Case: Connect laboratory systems, EHRs, and WHO databases

Capabilities:

       Pre-built connectors for HL7/FHIR integration

REST/SOAP API integration with laboratory information systems (LIS) Real-time data synchronization with WHO TrACSS system

Integration with antimicrobial susceptibility testing (AST) equipment Connection to pharmacy management systems

ServiceNow Now Platform App Engine

Use Case: Custom applications for specialized AMR workflows

Capabilities:

Low-code/no-code development

Custom data models for pathogen taxonomy, antibiotic classifications Workflow automation for antibiotic stewardship reviews

Business rules for automated alerts

Mobile app development for field surveillance

 

ServiceNow Mobile Studio

Use Case: Field surveillance and rural healthcare worker access

Capabilities:

     Offline-capable mobile data collection   

    GPS-enabled case reporting

    Push notifications for urgent alerts 

   Barcode scanning for drug tracking

ServiceNow Emergency Response Management

Use Case: Coordinate response to AMR outbreaks

Capabilities:

Incident command structure setup Resource mobilization and tracking Multi-agency coordination

Communication hub for stakeholders Crisis timeline management

ServiceNow Field Service Management

Use Case: Dispatch infection control teams and mobile laboratories

Capabilities:

Work order management for outbreak investigations Technician dispatch and scheduling

Mobile access for field teams

Equipment and supply tracking Route optimization

ServiceNow Service Portal & UI Builder

Use Case: Public-facing portal and customized interfaces

Capabilities:

Branded portal for different stakeholder groups

 Responsive design for all devices

Multilingual support (critical for global deployment)

Accessibility compliance (WCAG)

Custom widgets for data visualization

 

ServiceNow AI & Machine Learning

Use Case: Intelligent AMR prediction, detection, and decision support

  Capabilities:

  • Predictive Outbreak Detection

              ML models to forecast resistance outbreaks 2-4 weeks in advance

              Real-time anomaly detection identifying unusual resistance clusters

             Risk scoring algorithms predicting outbreak probability by facility/region

  • Smart Antibiotic Recommendations

              AI-powered clinical decision support based on local resistance patterns

             Treatment efficacy prediction using patient history and infection type

             Alternative therapy recommendations when first-line antibiotics show resistance

  • Natural Language Processing (NLP)

               Automated data extraction from unstructured lab reports and clinical notes

               Multi-language translation of AMR reports (20+ languages)

               Voice-to-text conversion for field surveillance workers

  • Computer Vision & Image Recognition

                Automated pathogen identification from microscopy images

               Bacterial colony counting and measurement from culture plates

               Quality control assessment of laboratory samples

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

Platform Requirements:

  • ServiceNow Orlando release or later for advanced analytics capabilities
  • Health & Life Sciences plugin, Performance Analytics, IntegrationHub subscription, Mobile Studio license, and Emergency Response Management plugin

Integration Requirements:

  • Laboratory Information Systems (LIS) with HL7 v2.x/FHIR R4 compatibility and REST API endpoints
  • Electronic Health Records (EHR) integration via FHIR API (Epic/Cerner/Allscripts connectors)
  • WHO TrACSS System API for standardized global reporting
  • Laboratory equipment integration (VITEK, MicroScan, BD Phoenix) for automated susceptibility testing

Infrastructure:

  • ServiceNow cloud instance with multi-region deployment, AES-256 encryption, and CDN for global access
  • HIPAA and GDPR compliance configuration with role-based access control and audit logging

AI/ML Dependencies:

  • Machine learning frameworks for predictive analytics and outbreak forecasting
  • NLP engines for unstructured data extraction and multi-language translation
  • Computer vision models for pathogen image recognition

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

Data Privacy & Security: Handling sensitive patient information across borders with varying regulations (HIPAA, GDPR). Mitigation: Data anonymization, region-specific instances, role-based access controls.

Data Standardization: Different countries use different coding systems and terminologies. Mitigation: Adopt WHONET format, implement SNOMED CT/LOINC mappings, use dropdown options instead of free text.

Low Digital Literacy: Healthcare workers in resource-limited settings may lack technical skills. Mitigation: Intuitive UI design, voice-to-text reporting, multilingual support, video tutorials, train-the-trainer programs.

Connectivity Issues: Unreliable internet in remote/rural areas. Mitigation: Offline-first mobile apps, SMS-based reporting fallback, local data caching, low-bandwidth optimization.

Integration Complexity: Diverse legacy healthcare systems. Mitigation: Pre-built connectors, HL7/FHIR adapters, comprehensive API documentation, manual upload alternatives.

Stakeholder Coordination: Aligning hospitals, governments, WHO, and NGOs with different priorities. Mitigation: Governance committee, customized dashboards, clear data-sharing agreements, regular steering meetings.

Funding Sustainability: Long-term platform maintenance. Mitigation: Phased implementation, multi-year grants (WHO, Gates Foundation), public-private partnerships, tiered pricing model.
